pageContent._comments: JSON object that contains data for page labels, buttons, etc.

_common.name: Asynchronously callable flows
_common.shortDescription: Learn how to use the CallableFlowAsyncInvoke, CallableFlowAsyncResponse, CallableInput, and CallableReply nodes to divide processing between message flows.
_common._resourceToOpenComment: The ID of the first resource to open when the user imports the tutorial. Resource IDs are defined in the repo_metadata.json Tutorials listing on ot4i.

pageDetails._topicListComment: A short list of product concepts or tasks demonstrated by this tutorial

topicList.title: Testing asyncronously callable flows on the same machine, same node, same integration server.
Testing asyncronously callable flows on the same machine, same node, different integration server.
Testing asyncronously callable flows on the same machine, different nodes.
Testing asyncronously callable flows on different machines

pageDetails._outcomesComment: A description of what the user will have learned or accomplished by running this tutorial.

outcomeList.title: Understand how to make asyncronous remote calls between message flows, on single or multiple integration servers, and on single or multiple integration nodes on the same or different machines.

summary._overviewComment: A short description of what happens in this tutorial, and an optional short explanation of the IIB concepts used in this tutorial if necessary for context. What background knowledge must the user have for this to make sense?

sections.section: This tutorial shows how different parts of an application can be split between different processes, by using asyncronously callable flow nodes.
The scenarios show flows deployed to the following destinations:
1) The same integration server.
2) A different integration server on the same integration node.
3) Different integration nodes on the same machine.
4) Different machines.

helpLinks._helpLinksComment: Helplinks that have a type:web attribute are rendered as web links. Otherwise, links are assumed to be to embedded Help topics in the Knowledge Center.
helpLinks.title: Find out more

details.title: Knowledge Center link to
details.description: Developing integration solutions by using applications

overview.name: Create
overview.heading: Import projects
overview._createComment: A description of what will happen when the user clicks Import.

sections.section: When you click Import, the following applications are created in your workspace:
• CallingFlowRequest implements the message flow - "CallableRequest.msgflow" which has a CallableFlowAsyncInvoke node.
• CalledFlow has a single flow called "CalledFlow.msgflow" which includes a CallableInput node and a CallableReply node.
• CallingFlowResponse implements the message flow - "CallableResponse.msgflow" which has a CallableFlowAsyncResponse node.
Throughout the scenarios in this tutorial, the CallingFlowRequest and CallingFlowResponse applications are deployed to the same integration server.

During the first of the scenarios, the CalledFlow application is deployed to the same integration server as the CallingFlowRequest and CallingFlowResponse applications. During subsequent scenarios, the CalledFlow application is deployed to a different integration server, then to a different node, and finally to a different machine. This is explained in more detail when you move on to the Prepare tab, along with the setup steps that you need to complete before running the flows.

details.title: Knowledge Center link to
details.description: Developing integration solutions by using applications

overview.name: Prepare
overview.heading: Trace node, configuration files, switch server, integration nodes and integration servers.
overview._prepareComment: A description of what just happened when the user clicked Import, and what will happen when the user clicks Deploy.

sections.section: You need to create a configuration file, a switch server and a number of integration nodes and integration servers which will be used in the tutorial. It is important to create these in the order shown below.
TRACE NODE. This must be edited to suit your local environment.
Windows / Linux

details.details: Open CallableRequest.msgflow, in the CallingFlowRequest application, and double-click the Trace node to open the Properties tab.
In the Destination field, select File from the drop-down menu.
In the File path field, enter a suitable path and file name to receive the trace output e.g. C:\temp\CallableRequestFlow.txt
In the pattern field, type ${Body}
For all other fields, accept the default values.
In the toolkit menu, select File > Save.

sections.section: CONFIGURATION FILES AND SWITCH SERVER.  Create these on your local machine by completing the following steps:
Windows

details.details: Create a mapped network drive on your local machine, which can be accessed by the remote machine.
Launch the IBM Integration Console.

Run the following command to create the switch configuration files:
iibcreateswitchcfg /output output /hostname hostname
(where output is the mapped network drive created above and hostname is the full machine name and domain of your local machine.)

The above command should produce the following screen messages:

Generated self signed certificate file output\ adminClient.p12
Generated self signed certificate file output\ switch.json
Generated self signed certificate file output\ agentx.json

Run the following command to create the switch server:
iibswitch create switch /config output/switch.json
(where output is the mapped network drive created above.)

The above command should produce the following screen messages:

Creating iibswitch component 'switch', please wait...
iibswitch created and started.

Run the mqsilist command to confirm that the switch server has been succesfully created and started:
mqsilist IIBSWITCH_NODE

The above command should produce the following screen messages:

BIP1286I: Integration server 'IIBSWITCH_SERVER' on integration node 'IIBSWITCH_NODE' is running.
BIP8071I: Successful command completion.

sections.section: Linux

details.details: Ensure that you are logged in using a user ID that has authority to run mqsi commands.
Create a shared folder on your local machine, which can be accessed by the remote machine.

Run the mqsiprofile command to set up the command environment:
install_dir/server/bin/mqsiprofile
(where install_dir is the location of your IIB installation e.g. /opt/ibm/iib-v.0.0.n)

Run the following command to create the switch configuration files:
iibcreateswitchcfg /output output /hostname hostname
(where output is the mapped network drive created above and hostname is the full machine name and domain of your local machine.)

The above command should produce the following screen messages:

Generated self signed certificate file output\ adminClient.p12
Generated self signed certificate file output\ switch.json
Generated self signed certificate file output\ agentx.json

Type the following command to create the switch server:
iibswitch create switch /config output/switch.json
(where output is the mapped network drive created above.)

The above command should produce the following screen messages:

Creating iibswitch component 'switch', please wait...
iibswitch created and started.

Run the mqsilist command to confirm that the switch server has been succesfully created and started:
mqsilist IIBSWITCH_NODE

The above command should produce the following screen messages:

BIP1286I: Integration server 'IIBSWITCH_SERVER' on integration node 'IIBSWITCH_NODE' is running.
BIP8071I: Successful command completion.

sections.section: NODELOCAL1 with two integration servers -  serverlocal1A and serverlocal1B.
Create these using the Development Toolkit on your local machine
Windows / Linux

details.details: In the Integration Development perspective, select the Integration Nodes view.
Right-click the Integration Nodes folder, and click New > Local Integration Node. The New Local Integration Node wizard is displayed.
Enter a name for the integration node. (NODELOCAL1). For this tutorial a queue manager is not required so you can ignore the option to enter a queue manager name.
On Windows, enter your user name and password. These parameters are not required on Linux.
Optional: On Windows, select whether to start the integration node automatically when Windows starts.
Enter a name for the default integration server (serverlocal1A) .
You have the option of entering a value for the flow debug port for the integration server; however, it is not be required for this tutorial so you can ignore this option.
Click Finish.
In the Integration Development perspective, select the Integration Nodes view.
Right-click the Integration Nodes NODELOCAL1, which you have just created. The New Integration Server wizard is displayed.
Enter a name for the new integration server (serverlocal1B) .
Click OK. The new integration server is created, started, and is visible in the Integration Nodes view of the Development Perspective.

sections.section: NODELOCAL2 with one integration server -  serverlocal2.
Create these on your local machine using steps 1 to 8 above, changing the names of integration node and integration server as required.
NODEREMOTE with one integration server -  serverremote.
Create these on a remote machine using steps 1 to 8 above, changing the names of integration node and integration server as required.
RUN CONNECTIVITY AGENT -  use the mqsichangeproperties command for each integration server where flows will be deployed.

Windows / Linux
(NOTE:Use the command line to run these steps.)

details.details:
mqsichangeproperties NODELOCAL1 -e serverlocal1A -o ComIbmIIBSwitchManager -n agentXConfigFile -p /output/agentx.json
(where output is the shared directory created above )

The above command should produce the following screen message:

BIP8071I: Successful command completion.

mqsistop NODELOCAL1

The above command should produce the following screen message:

BIP8071I: Successful command completion.

mqsistart NODELOCAL1

The above command should produce the following screen message:

BIP8071I: BIP8096I: Successful command initiation, check the system log to ensure that the component started without problem and that it continues to run without problem.

mqsilist NODELOCAL1

The above command should produce the following screen message:

BIP1325I: Integration node 'NODELOCAL1' with administration URI 'http://machine:port' is running.
(where machine is the name of the machine where the integration node has been created, and port is the port number on which the node is running )

mqsireportproperties NODELOCAL1 -e serverlocal1A -o ComIbmIIBSwitchManager/AgentX -r

The above command should produce the following screen message:

ComIbmIIBSwitchManager
uuid='ComIbmIIBSwitchManager'
agentx
url='wss://machine:9011'
started='TRUE'
name='agentx'
agentTransceiver
name='agentx'
tunnelToHQId='1'
currentOperationId='0'
sequenceId='1'
operation='0'
tunnelOpen='FALSE'
inFlightInboundConnections=''
inFlightOutboundConnections=''
remotelyCallableFlowManager
registeredFlows=''
registeredCallers=''

BIP8071I: Successful command completion.
(where machine is the full machine name and domain)

mqsireportproperties NODELOCAL1 -e serverlocal1A -o CallableFlowManager -r

The above command should produce the following screen message:

CallableFlowManager
uuid='CallableFlowManager'
userTraceLevel='none'
traceLevel='none'
userTraceFilter='none'
traceFilter='none'
delayReplyUntilFlowCommit='false'
disableRemoteInputRegistration='false'
redeployMessageTimeout='5'
remoteRetryTimeout='60'
retryLocalDuringDeploy='true'
retryRemoteUntilTimeout='true'
vrmfIntroducedAt='10.0.0.4'

BIP8071I: Successful command completion.

Repeat steps 1 to 6 changing the names of the integration node and integration server as required.
( for NODEREMOTE / serverremote you will have to run the commands on the remote machine)

sections.section:
If you have run all of the above setup correctly, you will now have the following integration nodes running on your local machine:

IIBSWITCH_NODE (This node is not visible in the toolkit. It can only be seen by running mqsilist in the command line. )
NODELOCAL1 (with integration servers serverlocal1A and serverlocal1B)
NODELOCAL2 (with integration server serverlocal2)

and on the remote machine:

NODEREMOTE (with integration server serverremote)
You are now ready to run the tutorial as described in the Run tab.

overview.name: Run
overview.heading: Follow these steps to complete the tutorial
overview._runComment: The full steps for the user to run through the tutorial. Use 'sections' to render paragraphs, 'steps' with a type of 'ordered' or 'unordered' to render HTML lists, and 'substeps' to render nested lists.

sections.section: SCENARIO 1 setup - All applications deployed to the same integration server.
You need to deploy the following message flows to the integration server serverlocal1A on NODELOCAL1
CallableFlowRequest.msgflow from the CallingFlowRequest application.
CalledFlow.msgflow from the CalledFlow application.

details.details: Open CallableRequest.msgflow, in the CallingFlowRequest application, and click the Flow Exerciser icon to deploy. If you are prompted where to deploy, ensure you that deploy to the integration server serverlocal1A. The Ready to Record Message window will be displayed. Click Close.

Open CallableResponse.msgflow, in the CallingFlowResponse application, and click the Flow Exerciser icon to deploy. If you are prompted where to deploy, ensure that you deploy to the integration server serverlocal1A on integration node NODELOCAL1. The Ready to Record Message window will be displayed. Click Close.

Open Called.msgflow, in the CalledFlow application, and click the Flow Exerciser icon to deploy. If you are prompted where to deploy, ensure that you deploy to the integration server serverlocal1A on integration node NODELOCAL1. The Ready to Record Message window will be displayed. Click Close.
Send a test message into CallableFlowRequest.msgflow, by following the steps in the SEND TEST MESSAGE section at the bottom of this page.

sections.section: SCENARIO 2 setup - CalledFlow application deployed to a different integration server on the same integration node.

You will to delete the CalledFlow application from the integration server serverlocal1A on integration node NODELOCAL1 and redeploy it to the integration server serverlocal1B on integration node NODELOCAL1

details.details: In the Integration Node view in the Development Toolkit, right click, navigate to the integration server serverlocal1A in NODELOCAL1 and right click on the deployed application CalledFlow.
Click Delete in the pop up menu and click on OK to confirm. The CalledFlow application is deleted from the integration server.

Open Called.msgflow, in the CalledFlow application and click the Flow Exerciser icon to deploy. If you are prompted where to deploy, ensure that you deploy to the integration server serverlocal1B on integration node NODELOCAL1. The Ready to Record Message window will be displayed. Click Close.
Send a test message into CallableFlowRequest.msgflow , by following the steps in the SEND TEST MESSAGE section at the bottom of this page.

sections.section: SCENARIO 3 setup - CalledFlow application deployed to a different integration node on the same machine.

You need to delete the CalledFlow application from the integration server serverlocal1B on integration node NODELOCAL1 and redeploy it to the integration server serverlocal2B on integration node NODELOCAL2

details.details: In the Integration Node view in the Development Toolkit, right-click, navigate to the integration server serverlocal1B in NODELOCAL1 and right-click the deployed application CalledFlow.
Click Delete in the pop-up menu and click OK to confirm. The CalledFlow application is deleted from the integration server.

Open Called.msgflow, in the CalledFlow application, and click the Flow Exerciser icon to deploy. If you are prompted where to deploy, ensure that you deploy to the integration server serverlocal2 on integration node NODELOCAL2. The Ready to Record Message window will be displayed. Click Close.
Send a test message into CallableFlowRequest.msgflow, by following the steps in the SEND TEST MESSAGE section at the bottom of this page.

sections.section: SCENARIO 4 setup - CalledFlow application deployed to a different integration node on a different machine.

You need to delete the CalledFlow application from the integration server serverlocal2 on integration node NODELOCAL2 and redeploy it to the integration server serverremote on integration node NODEREMOTE

details.details: In the Integration Node view in the Development Toolkit, right click, navigate to the integration server serverlocal2 in NODELOCAL2 and right click on the deployed application CalledFlow.
Click Delete in the pop-up menu and click on OK to confirm. The CalledFlow application is deleted from the integration server.

Open Called.msgflow, in the CalledFlow application and click the Flow Exerciser icon to deploy. If you are prompted where to deploy, ensure that you deploy to the integration server serverremote on integration node NODEREMOTE. The Ready to Record Message window will be displayed. Click Close.
Send a test message into CallableFlowRequest.msgflow following the steps in the SEND TEST MESSAGE section at the bottom of this page.

sections.section: SEND TEST MESSAGE.

details.details: Open CallableRequest.msgflow, in the CallingFlowRequest application.

Double-click the Compute node to display the ESQL code. Observe the description 'Entering callable flow response' and the environment setting 'UserContext.myPrivateData = 'Hello World!' this is data that is passed from CallableRequest.msgflow to CallableResponse.msgflow but which cannot be accessed by Called.msgflow.
Click the Send Message icon to select a message to send to the flow.
Choose the input message CallableFlowMessage. (For the purpose of this tutorial, an empty message is sent.) Click Send. Your request message is sent to the HTTP input node.

When the list of actions is shown, click on the Received HTTP reply message item to show the output from the flow. The output will contain timestamps showing when messages were entered and returned from flows. You will also see the text 'Entered CallableResponse flow :myPrivateData:Hello World!' As mentioned in the setup stages, this is data that is passed from CallableRequest.msgflow to CallableResponse.msgflow, but which cannot be accessed by Called.msgflow.}

After you close the dialog, the path taken through CallableRequest.msgflow is highlighted. Click on the message icon on each connection to see how the tree is updated by each node. In the message icon after the Compute Node and before the CallableFlowAsyncInvoke node, if you scroll to the bottom of the Recorded Message window, you will see a timestamp and a description 'Entering callable flow response.'

Examine the output from the Trace node in the file that you specified when you edited the node in the Prepare section of this tutorial
(e.g. C:\temp\CallableFlowRequest.txt)

The content of the file should be similar to the following, showing the timestamp when the message first entered CallableResponseFlow.msgflow and a later timestamp when it re-entered CallableResponseFlow.msgflow after being processed by CalledFlow.msgflow :

( ['json' : 0x16400ea0]
(0x01000000:Object):Data = (
(0x01000000:Object):Sequence = (
(0x03000000:NameValue):TimeStamp = TIMESTAMP '2017-06-26 12:46:42.358026' (TIMESTAMP)
(0x03000000:NameValue):Description = 'Entering callable flow response.' (CHARACTER)
)
)
)( ['json' : 0x16400ea0]
(0x01000000:Object):Data = (
(0x01000000:Object):Sequence = (
(0x03000000:NameValue):TimeStamp = TIMESTAMP '2017-06-26 12:47:50.674507' (TIMESTAMP)
(0x03000000:NameValue):Description = 'Entering callable flow response.' (CHARACTER)
)
)
)

sections.section: END OF TUTORIAL.
